PROF. BARNETT IS CO-AUTHOR
With Dr. McCabe, of Princeton, Publishes Book Discussing the Need
of Arbitration in Industrial
Disputes.

Dr. George E. Barnett, professor of statistics at Johns Hopkins,
and Dr. I). A. McCabe, assistant
professor of economics at Princeton University, have recently published a bdok on "Mediation, Investigation and Arbitration in Industrial Disputes." This book is
based on the work done in 1915
by Professor Barnett and Professor McCabe for the Government
Commission on Industrial Relations. The authors decided to
publish their views on the subject
independently of the report of the
commission.
Coining at a time when the
eyes of the country are turned on
the settling of disputes between
railroad employers and employees,
this study on the possibilities of
mediation of differences arising
between capital and labor is particularly significant. The authors
discuss mediation, investigation
and arbitration in industrial disputes both as a State and a National issue; confining themselves,
however, to the problems in the
United States, and not applying
their ideas to other countries.
In the book the existing laws
on mediation and arbitration are
thoroughly reviewed, and their results, both good and bad, are
noted. After a complete resume
of the problems involved, plans
are submitted by the writers for
a new system of control of industrial disputes. In the proposed
plans the best features of present
laws are included, and the inefficiencies of the existing methods
are guarded against.
The plans call for a chief mediator and two assistant mediators
in each State. In special cases a
State board of arbitration and a
State board of mediation and investigation are to be also provided.
The duties of each division are
carefully mapped out and detailed
plans given for the handling of
the various labor disputes within
the State.
The plans for the nation as a
whole include a mediation commission appointed by the President, and an industrial council,
made up of representatives of the
ten leading employers'associations
and the ten leading employees' organizations in the country.
The whole book is remarkable
for the clearness of concept and
the lucidity of treatment with
which all the aspects of the involved question of mediation are
discussed.

Dr. Park, Head of New York City Research Department, Addresses
Large Audience in C. E.
Building.

One of the largest audiences
that has ever collected in the Assembly hall in the Civil Engineering Building heard the lecture on
Wednesday afternoon, given by
Dr. William H. Park, head of the
Research Department of New
York city, on the danger of impure milk.
The lecture was held under the
joint auspices of the Johns Hopkins University and the Woman's
Civic League, and was illustrated
by slides. Pictures were shown of
how, in may cases, the milk is
carelessly handled and little precaution is taken against impurities. It was explained how, in
New York, every possible precaution is taken to prevent contamination while the milk is being
handled in its delivery to the customers.
According to Doctor Park, milk
is one of the most nutritious
of the dairy products, and on this
basis also far surpasses many
other foods. A half-pint of milk,
it was stated, contained as much
nourishment as two eggs.

Relief for the War Prisoners.

It is hard—almost impossible
—for the average college man,
pursuing his routine life, enjoying his accustomed pleasures, to
realize that in Europe 'millions
of men not one whit different
from himself are fighting, suffering and dying. The thing is so
monstrous, so volcanic, that the
first crash of horror has gone;
the war, to most of us, has become a vague abnormality, talked
of in terms of defeats and victories—infinitely remote. Realization can come only in sudden
gusts—gusts sweeping the country from end to end—resulting in
a riotousness of giving of which
the world has never seen a parallel. Those gusts represent a
sudden awakening, a passionate
desire to help,in the puny way that
we can help, a struggling humanity. Such was the movement
which resulted in the sending of
tens of millions to homeless Belgium ; such was the movement
which sent thousands of young
Americans to Europe to serve in
ambulance corps; such is the
movement which today becomes a
personal appeal to every Hopkins
man.
The condition of the prisoners
confined in European war camps
has been partly described elsewhere in this issue; it has not been
fully described; some of the most

horrible of the details have been
withheld. Yet, in times such as
these the most vivid of words are
powerless to those who have not
seen with their own eyes the conception of the misery; the loathsomeness, the racking, mind-destroying monotony of those camps
is beyond all comprehension.
One thing alone is clear. To
the men of the colleges and universities of America has come a
great opportunity; an opportunity, by their own individual efforts, to ameliorate the condition
of a body of men which represents
in its midst every class of the social order—the laborer and the
student.
This should be more than a
grubbing appeal or an unwilling,
listless contribution. The sum to
be donated by Hopkins should be
a sum given voluntarily—gladly—
for the performance of a great
work. It is not a matter of going
through with an obvious duty;
the thing is far bigger than that.
It is a matter of every man realizing that here he can help, here
he can do his part, however small
—realizing it through the medium
of personal sacrifice.
The Next step.
The most noticeable feature of
the present football situation is
the fact that no one knows exactly what that situation is. There
is no clear-cut issue, no sharp defining of attitude. It is not exactly a question of whether we
want undergraduate football or
not, because a good many of those
opposed to the present system are
also opposed to any system which
would eliminate from participation in Hopkins athletics the not
inconsiderable class of graduates
who come out for teams for the
sole reason that they Are personally and loyally interested. Nor
is the present agitation by any
means a thoughtless reaction to
an unsuccessful season. The dissatisfaction goes deeper than
that; it represents ideals which
have been stirring within the University since its conception, and
which ultimately are bound to be
realized. In the minds of some,
that ultimate goal is still distant; in the minds of others, it
is here. Meanwhile, the greatest
danger of all is that the discussion will not be definitely settled.
To THE NEWS-LETTER, the whole
question is this: What policy is
best for the Hopkins football
team to pursue? If the best poli-

cy is one of strictly undergraduate football, well and good. If it
is, a four-year rule, well and good.
If -it is the present system of recruiting a team by the grace of
Providence, well and good. But,
in the name of all logic and common sense, let us know in which
direction we are going. Let us
neither adopt a new system nor
adhere to an old one on the score
of general principles.
There are four parties vitally
interested in the football question, each of whom has a perspective of its own. They are the
undergraduate students, the graduate students, the alumni and the
faculty. No system can be successful until every one of those
classes is heartily behind it. No
plan can be considered adequate
unless it takes the attitude of
each of those classes into consideration. In the heat of argument, a somewhat important fact
is occasionally forgotten—namely, that the motive under which
every Hopkins man is operating
is one of consideration of what
will be to the best interests of
the University as a whole.
For that reaion, and because it
.belleves that in this direction lies
the only sane, logical solution of
the present crisis, THE NEWSLETTER proposes the following
plan: Let a committee be appointed by President Goodnow, on
which shall be representatives of

Why Hopkins Men Should Help.
By AVRA E. LINDLEY,
General Secretary of the Y. M. C. A.

The college and university men
of America are called upon to
raise $150,000 to help our suffering brothers in the warring nations of Europe. The crying need
of the five and one-half million
men .and boys in the prison
camps, suffering what at best
must be great privation, and of
the more than five million in hospitals, to say nothing of the millions in actual fighting armies, is
the warrant for this appeal to the
men of Johns Hopkins University.
We do not claim that the raising of $1,000 among the Hopkins
students and faculty will discharge our obligation or meet our
responsibility—it is only sharing
in a meagre way. When in our
imagination we visit the thousands of prison camps, where, under the best possible circumstances, there is suffering from
loneliness, hunger, cold and sickness, we are face to face with an
indescribable condition. The intense cold weather of the third
year of the war is upon the men
and the need of food and clothing
is overwhelming. We cannot afford to live here in a land of
plenty, with comfort and luxury,
while our fellow-students in Europe face death from the lack of
food and clothing. When men
who stand in peril of their lives
on the battlefield gladly minister
to those who are in greater distress than themselves—sometimes
their enemies—the students of the
United States in the physical security of neutrality should not be
content until they have exhausted
their ingenuity in manifesting
their practical sympathy and
helpfulness.
No language can exaggerate the
desperate condition of the men
and boys in the prison camps.
We are confronted with an appeal to help to the limit of our
ability.
Other college and university
students are sacrificing that they
may answer this Call for service.
We believe the men here at Hopkins are just as loyal and eager
to sacrifice for the students of
Europe as they are in any other
institution.
This movement deserves the
support of every man in the University. All should give, and some
should give largely.

To the Editor of THE News-LETTER:
Sir—I havefollowed with interest
the discussion which is prevalent
about the University, and which
hinges on the football situation
here, and I believe that nothing
could do Hopkins athletics more
good. It has caused the other
teams to look to their own weaknesses, and a general sprucing up
all around in spirit and aggressiveness has been a direct result.
And all this came from blaming
the football team when the football team was not to blame.
As to the situation here, although it is indeed deplorable, the
football team is not the cause.
This team is not the speck on the
apple. It is but the flagrant and
visible result of a rotten core.
The criticisms and suggestions
which have so far appeared have
in the main dealt with football,
whereas the trouble lies higher
up. The trouble, unfortunately,
is not with the men, nor the
spirit, but with the method of
governing and training these men
and our athletics in general.
I am not referring to Corner,
or to Sutton, or to the other members of the Athletic Board, or to
the coaches. All of these men are
conscientiously and ably fulfilling their functions. They can do
no more than they are doing under the present policy. They
should in fact be congratulated
on doing so well. It is not the
men—it is the system. Hopkins,
like every other up-to-the-minute
college not of the 22-calibre type,
needs a man at the head of a
radical, intelligent organization
who knows his business, and is
able to meet men, give them good
advice, clear-sighted supervision,
and what is just as important,
all of his time. And while Hopkins needs such a man and such a
system, she has been extremely
slow in adopting them. Harvard
has Sargent, a forceful, capable
man, who has• studied conditions
at Cambridge and is in a position
to direct them to advantage. Virginia has Lambeth, and Lambeth
has made Virginia. Before he
came, athletics there were slipshod, uncertain, and in a general
slump, with stock at about 100
below par. Since his installation
Virginia's teams are met with
deep respect and are usually winning ones. Lambeth has put them
on their feet and he has made athletics there.

We need such a man! We need
a man who can follow conditions
here, give advice to, our men, direct athletics, supervise the coaching, training and management of
our teams; who can meet our fellows man to man, tell them what
they ought to know, keep them
on the job while they should be
on it, and take them off at the
first signs of disability or staleness. We need a man who can be
on the job all day long, who can
look after equipment and the
track and playing fields, and the
conditioning of these latter. A
man who knows athletics and athletes, and the conditions surroudding both.
Such men are available and it
is up to us to get one. We want
an up-to-the-minute wide-awake
American to take Charge of our
athletics and until we get one
our athletics will never be above
"fair to middlin'," and they'll be
lucky to stay there. It's not our
fellows, it's not our coaches, and
it's not our graduate managers
that are responsible for our decrepit athletic condition; but it is
the system under which they try
to operate, and it is the lack of a
definite, systematized, on-the-job
head—a head with brains on the
inside and eyes on the outside,
and lots, of both. We haven't
such a man — sad to say, we
haven't any man—and until we
get one, you can keep on making
four-year rules and keep on barring meds and'
keep on hiring sundry and divers coaches until Hopkins is history and history forgotten and we won't have better
teams.
So let's get busy. Don't pick
out the football team to heap our
righteous indignation upon. We
may lance a boil and get some
of the pus out, but unless we
take a tonic to cleanse the whole
system, we'll soon be lancing
again, and more than likely
there'll be two instead of one.
Don't let's lance, let's doctor; and
when we do doctor, let's get a
specialist's advice and leave the
quacks alone.
HENRY LOBE STRAUS.
December 7, 1916.

TWO PROFESSORS TO BE LOST
Doctors Armstrong and Marden, of the
Department of Romance, Have Both
Accepted Positions at Princeton University.

Edward Cooke Armstrong, Ph.
D., and Charles Carroll Marden,
Ph. D., both for years connected
with the Department of the Romance Languages of Johns Hopkins University, have accepted appointments in Princeton University. Doctor Armstrong is to have
charge of the graduate work in
the French language in that institution, while Doctor Marden has
been appointed to fill the recently
created Ford professorship of
Spanish.
Doctor Armstrong is a graduate of Randolph-Macon College,
where he received his A. B. in
1890, and his A. M. in 1894. He
was a Fellow at Johns Hopkins
in 1896-97, receiving his Ph. D. in
the latter year. According to the
Princeton Alumni Magazine, "No
French scholar of his age has
played a more prominent part in
the training of young men for the
doctorate in French, or has insisted on a higher standard of
ability or accomplishment. His
own work in French philology
has won for him an international
reputation among scholars."
Doctor Marden received his A.
B. at Hopkins in 1889, and his
Ph. D. in 1894; he was instructor
in Spanish at the University of
Michigan in 1890-91. He is a
member of the Hispanic Society
of America, and a corresponding
member of the Royal Spanish
Academy. He is looked upon as
one of the leading Spanish scholars of the Americas.
While no successors to these
two men have as yet been appointed, every effort will be made
to maintain the high standard of
the Department of Romance Languages set by its founder, Professor Elliot, and so ably continued by Professors Armstrong
and Marden.

PROF. BARNETT IS CO-AUTHOR
With Dr. McCabe, of Princeton, Publishes Book Discussing the Need
of Arbitration in Industrial
Disputes.

Dr. George E. Barnett, professor of statistics at Johns Hopkins,
and Dr. I). A. McCabe, assistant
professor of economics at Princeton University, have recently published a bdok on "Mediation, Investigation and Arbitration in Industrial Disputes." This book is
based on the work done in 1915
by Professor Barnett and Professor McCabe for the Government
Commission on Industrial Relations. The authors decided to
publish their views on the subject
independently of the report of the
commission.
Coining at a time when the
eyes of the country are turned on
the settling of disputes between
railroad employers and employees,
this study on the possibilities of
mediation of differences arising
between capital and labor is particularly significant. The authors
discuss mediation, investigation
and arbitration in industrial disputes both as a State and a National issue; confining themselves,
however, to the problems in the
United States, and not applying
their ideas to other countries.
In the book the existing laws
on mediation and arbitration are
thoroughly reviewed, and their results, both good and bad, are
noted. After a complete resume
of the problems involved, plans
are submitted by the writers for
a new system of control of industrial disputes. In the proposed
plans the best features of present
laws are included, and the inefficiencies of the existing methods
are guarded against.
The plans call for a chief mediator and two assistant mediators
in each State. In special cases a
State board of arbitration and a
State board of mediation and investigation are to be also provided.
The duties of each division are
carefully mapped out and detailed
plans given for the handling of
the various labor disputes within
the State.
The plans for the nation as a
whole include a mediation commission appointed by the President, and an industrial council,
made up of representatives of the
ten leading employers'associations
and the ten leading employees' organizations in the country.
The whole book is remarkable
for the clearness of concept and
the lucidity of treatment with
which all the aspects of the involved question of mediation are
discussed.

Relief for the War Prisoners.

It is hard—almost impossible
—for the average college man,
pursuing his routine life, enjoying his accustomed pleasures, to
realize that in Europe 'millions
of men not one whit different
from himself are fighting, suffering and dying. The thing is so
monstrous, so volcanic, that the
first crash of horror has gone;
the war, to most of us, has become a vague abnormality, talked
of in terms of defeats and victories—infinitely remote. Realization can come only in sudden
gusts—gusts sweeping the country from end to end—resulting in
a riotousness of giving of which
the world has never seen a parallel. Those gusts represent a
sudden awakening, a passionate
desire to help,in the puny way that
we can help, a struggling humanity. Such was the movement
which resulted in the sending of
tens of millions to homeless Belgium ; such was the movement
which sent thousands of young
Americans to Europe to serve in
ambulance corps; such is the
movement which today becomes a
personal appeal to every Hopkins
man.
The condition of the prisoners
confined in European war camps
has been partly described elsewhere in this issue; it has not been
fully described; some of the most

horrible of the details have been
withheld. Yet, in times such as
these the most vivid of words are
powerless to those who have not
seen with their own eyes the conception of the misery; the loathsomeness, the racking, mind-destroying monotony of those camps
is beyond all comprehension.
One thing alone is clear. To
the men of the colleges and universities of America has come a
great opportunity; an opportunity, by their own individual efforts, to ameliorate the condition
of a body of men which represents
in its midst every class of the social order—the laborer and the
student.
This should be more than a
grubbing appeal or an unwilling,
listless contribution. The sum to
be donated by Hopkins should be
a sum given voluntarily—gladly—
for the performance of a great
work. It is not a matter of going
through with an obvious duty;
the thing is far bigger than that.
It is a matter of every man realizing that here he can help, here
he can do his part, however small
—realizing it through the medium
of personal sacrifice.
The Next step.
The most noticeable feature of
the present football situation is
the fact that no one knows exactly what that situation is. There
is no clear-cut issue, no sharp defining of attitude. It is not exactly a question of whether we
want undergraduate football or
not, because a good many of those
opposed to the present system are
also opposed to any system which
would eliminate from participation in Hopkins athletics the not
inconsiderable class of graduates
who come out for teams for the
sole reason that they Are personally and loyally interested. Nor
is the present agitation by any
means a thoughtless reaction to
an unsuccessful season. The dissatisfaction goes deeper than
that; it represents ideals which
have been stirring within the University since its conception, and
which ultimately are bound to be
realized. In the minds of some,
that ultimate goal is still distant; in the minds of others, it
is here. Meanwhile, the greatest
danger of all is that the discussion will not be definitely settled.
To THE NEWS-LETTER, the whole
question is this: What policy is
best for the Hopkins football
team to pursue? If the best poli-

cy is one of strictly undergraduate football, well and good. If it
is, a four-year rule, well and good.
If -it is the present system of recruiting a team by the grace of
Providence, well and good. But,
in the name of all logic and common sense, let us know in which
direction we are going. Let us
neither adopt a new system nor
adhere to an old one on the score
of general principles.
There are four parties vitally
interested in the football question, each of whom has a perspective of its own. They are the
undergraduate students, the graduate students, the alumni and the
faculty. No system can be successful until every one of those
classes is heartily behind it. No
plan can be considered adequate
unless it takes the attitude of
each of those classes into consideration. In the heat of argument, a somewhat important fact
is occasionally forgotten—namely, that the motive under which
every Hopkins man is operating
is one of consideration of what
will be to the best interests of
the University as a whole.
For that reaion, and because it
.belleves that in this direction lies
the only sane, logical solution of
the present crisis, THE NEWSLETTER proposes the following
plan: Let a committee be appointed by President Goodnow, on
which shall be representatives of
the undergraduates, the Medical
School students, the Alumni Association and the faculty. Let
that committee be instructed to
prepare a statement canvassing
the desirability of a change in the
football situation, and, if it decides that such a change is necessary, stating just what the new
policy should be. Finally, let
that report be submitted to each
body represented.
Such a plan would guarantee
two things a thorough knowledge of the entire situation and a
possibility of definite, constructive action. Without such a plan,
nothing can be accomplished. Yet,
in the plan itself, we believe that
there can be nothing antagonistic
to either the advocate of the present system or the advocate of undergraduate football. If the present agitation is unnecessary and
harmful, it will be so proved. If,
on the other hand, undergraduate
football is a desirable thing, the
way will be open for its adoption.
The committee,it is to be supposed,
would be composed of such representative men as the president of
the Alumni Association, the graduate manager and the president
of the Athletic Association. The
work of such a committee would
of necessity be both thorough and
impartial, and it would bear witness to a co-ordination in which,
unfortunately, Hopkins affairs
have sometimes been notably lacking.

Why Hopkins Men Should Help.
By AVRA E. LINDLEY,
General Secretary of the Y. M. C. A.

The college and university men
of America are called upon to
raise $150,000 to help our suffering brothers in the warring nations of Europe. The crying need
of the five and one-half million
men .and boys in the prison
camps, suffering what at best
must be great privation, and of
the more than five million in hospitals, to say nothing of the millions in actual fighting armies, is
the warrant for this appeal to the
men of Johns Hopkins University.
We do not claim that the raising of $1,000 among the Hopkins
students and faculty will discharge our obligation or meet our
responsibility—it is only sharing
in a meagre way. When in our
imagination we visit the thousands of prison camps, where, under the best possible circumstances, there is suffering from
loneliness, hunger, cold and sickness, we are face to face with an
indescribable condition. The intense cold weather of the third
year of the war is upon the men
and the need of food and clothing
is overwhelming. We cannot afford to live here in a land of
plenty, with comfort and luxury,
while our fellow-students in Europe face death from the lack of
food and clothing. When men
who stand in peril of their lives
on the battlefield gladly minister
to those who are in greater distress than themselves—sometimes
their enemies—the students of the
United States in the physical security of neutrality should not be
content until they have exhausted
their ingenuity in manifesting
their practical sympathy and
helpfulness.
No language can exaggerate the
desperate condition of the men
and boys in the prison camps.
We are confronted with an appeal to help to the limit of our
ability.
Other college and university
students are sacrificing that they
may answer this Call for service.
We believe the men here at Hopkins are just as loyal and eager
to sacrifice for the students of
Europe as they are in any other
institution.
This movement deserves the
support of every man in the University. All should give, and some
should give largely.

To the Editor of THE News-LETTER:
Sir—I havefollowed with interest
the discussion which is prevalent
about the University, and which
hinges on the football situation
here, and I believe that nothing
could do Hopkins athletics more
good. It has caused the other
teams to look to their own weaknesses, and a general sprucing up
all around in spirit and aggressiveness has been a direct result.
And all this came from blaming
the football team when the football team was not to blame.
As to the situation here, although it is indeed deplorable, the
football team is not the cause.
This team is not the speck on the
apple. It is but the flagrant and
visible result of a rotten core.
The criticisms and suggestions
which have so far appeared have
in the main dealt with football,
whereas the trouble lies higher
up. The trouble, unfortunately,
is not with the men, nor the
spirit, but with the method of
governing and training these men
and our athletics in general.
I am not referring to Corner,
or to Sutton, or to the other members of the Athletic Board, or to
the coaches. All of these men are
conscientiously and ably fulfilling their functions. They can do
no more than they are doing under the present policy. They
should in fact be congratulated
on doing so well. It is not the
men—it is the system. Hopkins,
like every other up-to-the-minute
college not of the 22-calibre type,
needs a man at the head of a
radical, intelligent organization
who knows his business, and is
able to meet men, give them good
advice, clear-sighted supervision,
and what is just as important,
all of his time. And while Hopkins needs such a man and such a
system, she has been extremely
slow in adopting them. Harvard
has Sargent, a forceful, capable
man, who has• studied conditions
at Cambridge and is in a position
to direct them to advantage. Virginia has Lambeth, and Lambeth
has made Virginia. Before he
came, athletics there were slipshod, uncertain, and in a general
slump, with stock at about 100
below par. Since his installation
Virginia's teams are met with
deep respect and are usually winning ones. Lambeth has put them
on their feet and he has made athletics there.

We need such a man! We need
a man who can follow conditions
here, give advice to, our men, direct athletics, supervise the coaching, training and management of
our teams; who can meet our fellows man to man, tell them what
they ought to know, keep them
on the job while they should be
on it, and take them off at the
first signs of disability or staleness. We need a man who can be
on the job all day long, who can
look after equipment and the
track and playing fields, and the
conditioning of these latter. A
man who knows athletics and athletes, and the conditions surroudding both.
Such men are available and it
is up to us to get one. We want
an up-to-the-minute wide-awake
American to take Charge of our
athletics and until we get one
our athletics will never be above
"fair to middlin'," and they'll be
lucky to stay there. It's not our
fellows, it's not our coaches, and
it's not our graduate managers
that are responsible for our decrepit athletic condition; but it is
the system under which they try
to operate, and it is the lack of a
definite, systematized, on-the-job
head—a head with brains on the
inside and eyes on the outside,
and lots, of both. We haven't
such a man — sad to say, we
haven't any man—and until we
get one, you can keep on making
four-year rules and keep on barring meds and'
keep on hiring sundry and divers coaches until Hopkins is history and history forgotten and we won't have better
teams.
So let's get busy. Don't pick
out the football team to heap our
righteous indignation upon. We
may lance a boil and get some
of the pus out, but unless we
take a tonic to cleanse the whole
system, we'll soon be lancing
again, and more than likely
there'll be two instead of one.
Don't let's lance, let's doctor; and
when we do doctor, let's get a
specialist's advice and leave the
quacks alone.
HENRY LOBE STRAUS.
December 7, 1916.

TWO PROFESSORS TO BE LOST
Doctors Armstrong and Marden, of the
Department of Romance, Have Both
Accepted Positions at Princeton University.

Edward Cooke Armstrong, Ph.
D., and Charles Carroll Marden,
Ph. D., both for years connected
with the Department of the Romance Languages of Johns Hopkins University, have accepted appointments in Princeton University. Doctor Armstrong is to have
charge of the graduate work in
the French language in that institution, while Doctor Marden has
been appointed to fill the recently
created Ford professorship of
Spanish.
Doctor Armstrong is a graduate of Randolph-Macon College,
where he received his A. B. in
1890, and his A. M. in 1894. He
was a Fellow at Johns Hopkins
in 1896-97, receiving his Ph. D. in
the latter year. According to the
Princeton Alumni Magazine, "No
French scholar of his age has
played a more prominent part in
the training of young men for the
doctorate in French, or has insisted on a higher standard of
ability or accomplishment. His
own work in French philology
has won for him an international
reputation among scholars."
Doctor Marden received his A.
B. at Hopkins in 1889, and his
Ph. D. in 1894; he was instructor
in Spanish at the University of
Michigan in 1890-91. He is a
member of the Hispanic Society
of America, and a corresponding
member of the Royal Spanish
Academy. He is looked upon as
one of the leading Spanish scholars of the Americas.
While no successors to these
two men have as yet been appointed, every effort will be made
to maintain the high standard of
the Department of Romance Languages set by its founder, Professor Elliot, and so ably continued by Professors Armstrong
and Marden.
